titleStmt.title: AI Language Model Rivals Expert Ethicist in Perceived Moral Expertise

affiliation.orgName: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill

analytic.title: AI Language Model Rivals Expert Ethicist in Perceived Moral Expertise

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: People view AI as possessing expertise across various fields, but the perceived quality of AI-generated moral expertise remains uncertain. Recent work suggests that large language models (LLMs) perform well on tasks designed to assess moral alignment, reflecting moral judgments with relatively high accuracy. As LLMs are increasingly employed in decisionmaking roles, there is a growing expectation for them to offer not just aligned judgments but also demonstrate sound moral reasoning. Here, we advance work on the Moral Turing Test and find that Americans rate ethical advice from GPT-4o as slightly more moral, trustworthy, thoughtful, and correct than that of the popular New York Times advice column, The Ethicist. Participants perceived GPT models as surpassing both a representative sample of Americans and a renowned ethicist in delivering moral justifications and advice, suggesting that people may increasingly view LLM outputs as viable sources of moral expertise. This work suggests that people might see LLMs as valuable complements to human expertise in moral guidance and decision-making. It also underscores the importance of carefully programming ethical guidelines in LLMs, considering their potential to influence users' moral reasoning.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: People view AI as possessing expertise in many domains, applying it widely from translation services to drug discovery [1,2]; However, perceptions of the quality of AI-generated moral expertise remains uncertain. Recent work suggests that large language models (LLMs) can generate moral judgments that closely align with those of people [3][4][5][6], but perceptions of moral expertise go beyond merely reflecting human moral judgments. Perceived moral expertise also requires competence with moral reasoning-explaining or justifying why particular judgments are ethical. Here we find that Americans seem to perceive LLM advice as reflecting substantial moral expertise. The latest GPT models outperform American laypeople at justifying their moral judgments, and offer advice rated as more moral, trustworthy, correct, and thoughtful than that of the popular New York Times advice column The Ethicist.

What does it mean for AI to be perceived as an expert in a domain? In fields with clear objective criteria like engineering, expertise is fairly straightforward to determine, characterized by performing tasks exceptionally well according to measurable standards. However, the notion of expertise becomes more complex in subjective domains like morality [7]. Philosophers have long debated the concept of moral expertise, and people differ greatly in their moral views [8]. Moreover, the subjective nature of morality may make it impossible to identify genuine moral experts [9]. Despite this lack of objective standards, computer scientists have attempted to provide clear benchmarks for AI moral reasoning. The Moral Turing Test (MTT) was initially proposed to evaluate whether machines had attained human-level morality [10]. In this test, people attempt to discern between the moral reasoning of a machine and that of a human. A variant of the MTT, the Comparative Moral Turing Test (cMTT), posits that AI could be perceived as achieving human moral expertise if it meets or exceeds a human in moral reasoning (rather than being indistinguishable from a human; Allen et al., 2000). However, these tests leave open questions, like what it really means for a machine to morally reason like a person, and who its reasoning should be compared against.

One important way that people evaluate moral expertise in AI is the extent to which it appears to align with people's moral judgments [11]. Recent work has shown that modern LLMs often reflect similar moral intuitions as people in their outputs [12]. GPT models demonstrate high alignment with average moral judgments in the U.S., indicating that they can model moral values from their training data with high accuracy [4]. LLMs can also tailor their moral judgments based on users' political identities, and show skill at predicting people's judgments of more complex moral dilemmas from online posts [5,6]. Importantly, however, LLMs are limited in that their moral alignment is biased towards the Western populations that make up a disproportionate amount of their training data, and they often reduce variance and exaggerate average responses [13,14]. Additionally, moral alignment does not imply that LLMs engage in moral reasoning akin to human cognition; rather, it reflects the patterns they are trained to replicate.

A second way people evaluate expertise is by assessing alignment with the method behind arriving at moral judgments [15]. People make moral decisions by using their minds, relying on cognitive and emotional processes that focus on intentions, causal relationships, and outcomes-which some theories understand as perceptions of interpersonal harm [16][17][18][19]. Since AI lacks these mental processes and emotions, people often perceive it as less suitable for moral decisions [20][21][22]. While AI lacks human cognition, people tend to trust AI programs more when they understand their decision-making processes [23][24][25][26][27]. Studies have shown that people more readily accept article and joke recommendations from AI programs after learning how they were generated [23,28]. However, much like the opacity of moral reasoning in the human brain, algorithmic decisions are often made in a "black box." The inherent complexity of algorithms means that even AI researchers struggle to comprehend how LLM decisions are made [29]. This opacity underscores the importance of LLMs possessing the ability to clearly justify their moral advice. Since LLMs are too complex to convey their inner algorithmic workings, providing thoughtful justifications gives people a way to evaluate the reasoning behind AI moral judgments.

The ability to clearly communicate one's moral reasoning is a key criterion of moral expertise [30]. As Einstein expressed, "If you can't explain it simply, you don't understand it well enough." AI researchers have asserted that AI should be able to justify its moral decisions for transparency [31]. Laypeople also want AI programs that can provide clear justifications for their moral judgments. Participants in one study rated an LLM as highly morally competent but expressed low confidence in relying on it because it could not adequately explain its moral judgments [32]. As AI systems are increasingly deployed to make critical decisions in areas like healthcare and employment, their ability to provide clear justifications for their recommendations is essential to ensure their safety and fairness. Given the rising popularity of LLMs, it is also important that they provide high-quality advice and moral justifications to enable users to critically evaluate them.

Evaluating whether people perceive LLMs to possess moral expertise raises the question of who might be the standard of comparison for these tests. One could argue that everyday people are moral experts because all of us (except perhaps psychopaths; [33]) possess an innate moral sense honed by living culture [34]. Since moral values are socially determined, aligning with the majority of people in a given community is an important criterion for moral expertise [11,35]. Additionally, it could be argued that some people are specific moral experts [36]. Advisors, philosophers, and thought leaders bring a systematic understanding of morality, and are skilled in articulating the reasoning behind their decisions. People turn to such leaders for moral guidance, making them valuable benchmarks of how LLM moral reasoning is perceived.

The realm of morality is often perceived as beyond the capability of AI due to its complex and context-dependent nature. However, recent work suggests that LLMs can sometimes meet-or even outperform-laypeople in tasks related to perceptions of moral reasoning. LLMs have shown excellent performance on theory of mind tasks [37] but see [38], and have demonstrated the capacity to meet or surpass people in other domains like persuasion [39][40][41][42]. Past work indicates that people may see LLM-generated text as excelling in moral reasoning as well. For instance, Aharoni et al. (2024) [43] found that participants rated moral explanations written by GPT-4 as higher in quality than those written by undergraduates in an introductory philosophy course, and Howe et al. (2023) [44] found that GPT's advice was rated as more empathetic, complete, balanced, and helpful than that of professional advice columnists (although this study did not assess perceived morality). This work suggests that people may increasingly perceive LLM-generated text as effective in demonstrating moral reasoning.

Building on past research, the present work expands understanding of perceptions of LLM moral reasoning in four key ways. First, we provide a comprehensive assessment of how LLM moral reasoning is perceived by comparing it to both a renowned ethicist and representative sample of Americans. In doing so, we test whether perceptions of LLM moral advice can meet or surpass both the general population and professionals in moral expertise. Second, while most earlier studies focused on relatively simple moral scenarios, our study investigates perceptions of LLM advice in response to complex real-life moral dilemmas featured in an advice column. This allows us to test how people perceive the morality of LLM advice in practical contexts where they are increasingly being used [45][46][47]. Third, we investigate potential factors shaping these perceptions, including differences in the moral language used by LLMs compared to people, variations in tone between LLM-generated advice and human advice, and the relationship between moral alignment (the degree of moral agreement between advice givers and recipients) and perceptions of LLM-generated justifications and advice. Finally, we assess the robustness of these findings across the political spectrum and in scenarios that vary in their level of controversy.

LLMs may evoke perceptions of moral expertise through the use of appropriate language for compelling explanations. Previous work has found that LLMs use higher rates of moral language in their arguments, which partially accounts for their greater persuasiveness compared to people [48]. Evoking moral themes may also be particularly important for the perceived quality of LLM moral reasoning. A large body of work finds that moral language is highly engaging and widely shared on social media [49][50][51][52]. Moral language may therefore impact perceptions of LLM moral reasoning capacity. Here, we operationalize moral language using the extended Moral Foundations Dictionary (eMFD), which approximates the degree of moral themes in a text based on the prevalence of words associated with morality.

div.head: Present Research
div.p: We evaluate perceptions of LLM moral reasoning in two studies, assessing the perceived morality and advice quality of GPT models. First, we examine how people view GPT's ability to justify its moral decisions by comparing its explanations of its moral judgments to those written by people (n = 501). We next put GPT through a stronger test by comparing perceptions of its moral advice against that of an expert ethicist from The New York Times advice column The Ethicist (n = 900). In both studies, we examine how people perceive the moral soundness, trustworthiness, thoughtfulness, nuance, and correctness of GPT's justifications and advice compared to those of people. We also investigate whether participants can detect that GPT's justifications and advice are AI-generated. In Study 2, we analyze the language used by GPT and The Ethicist to examine whether GPT uses higher rates of moral language, and whether this helps explain differences in the perceived morality of its advice. If GPT is seen to perform as well or better than laypeople and moral experts in these studies, this would suggest that people perceive its advice to reflect moral expertise.

div.head: Study 1: Moral Justifications
div.p: One important way to evaluate perceptions of moral expertise in LLMs is to examine how people perceive their ability to justify moral judgments. We first investigated how people perceive GPT's moral reasoning by comparing its explanations for the morality of different scenarios with those provided by a representative sample of American participants from a previous survey (See Supplementary Information for survey details). To assess how GPT's moral reasoning is perceived, we measured participants' views of the moral soundness, trustworthiness, thoughtfulness, nuance, and correctness of its justifications. We conducted a Comparative Moral Turing Test (cMTT), which assesses whether AI-generated content meets or exceeds a human in perceived moral reasoning. If people perceive that GPT can provide clearer or more compelling justifications for its moral judgments than people, this would suggest that LLM outputs are viewed as reflecting moral expertise. We also explored whether participants could recognize moral justifications written by GPT as AI-generated, employing a traditional Moral Turing Test (MTT). By assessing both the recognizability and perceived quality of GPT's moral explanations, we aimed to understand whether people regard LLMs as possessing moral expertise according to these evaluative frameworks.

div.head: Ethics
div.p: This research protocol was approved by the Institutional Review Board of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. Informed consent was provided by all participants, and the study was performed in accordance with approved guidelines and regulations.

div.head: Preregistration
div.p: This study was pre-registered at https://osf.io/q5zt3.

div.head: Participants
div.p: We recruited 503 participants representative of the United States population (Mage = 43.30, SDage = 15.81) from the online recruitment platform Connect. Of these, 2 did not pass an attention check, leaving a remaining 501 participants. Participants were selected to be representative of the United States population based on ethnicity, gender, and age. 250 participants were women, 249 were men, and 1 participant was transgender. 57.2% of participants were White, 12.6% were Black, 10.8% were Asian, 13.6% were Hispanic or Latino/a/x, .8% were Native American or Alaskan Native, 3.6% were multiracial, and 1.4% did not specify their race.

div.head: GPT-3.5-turbo configuration
div.p: We prompted GPT-3.5-turbo with 79 moral scenarios from previously published papers [53][54][55][56] using the OpenAI API (See Supplementary Information for exact prompt). We adopted a popular prompting technique in NLP literature called Chain-of-Thought prompting [57]. This method encourages the model to break down reasoning into a series of intermediate steps, which helps in generating more structured and interpretable outputs. We considered four key dimensions (harm, help, vulnerability, intentionality) derived from the theory of dyadic morality [19]. In the prompt, we asked the model to generate scores between one and ten and write corresponding justifications along these dimensions for the scenario as intermediate reasoning steps. Then, we asked the model to generate a moral score for the scenario and write a corresponding justification. We specified a structured output format (JSON) to parse and extract relevant data for our study. To help ensure reproducibility in our experiment, we set the temperature to 0. We also set the maximum number of generated tokens to 1500.

div.head: Procedure
div.p: Participants first read 79 moral scenarios from previously published papers [53][54][55][56]. The scenarios described situations ranging from mundane transgressions like stealing Halloween candy to serious offenses like firing a gun into a crowd. Some of these actions were morally positive in valence, like giving food to those in need. Others were negative in valence, like swearing at a cashier. On average, six participants rated each scenario. Following these scenarios, participants read one justification for the degree of morality (or immorality) of the scenario written by GPT-3.5-turbo, and three written by participants in a representative sample of Americans from a former survey (See Supplementary Information for survey details). Participants were not made aware that one of the justifications was written by AI while rating the quality of the justifications. We presented three participant-written justifications to account for the high variability in human-written answers.

Participants rated the quality of each of the four justifications on scales from "1: Strongly disagree" to "7: Strongly agree". They rated the morality of the justification ("This explanation is morally correct"), the correctness of the justification ("I agree with this explanation"), the trustworthiness of the justification ("I trust the person who wrote this explanation"), the nuance of the justification ("This explanation takes the nuances of the situation into account"), and the thoughtfulness of the justification ("This explanation is thoughtful"). We selected these questions to assess the morality of the justifications, as well as qualities often associated with morality like trustworthiness. After answering questions about the justification quality, participants were next directed to a question in which they selected which of the four justifications they believed was written by AI. Each participant answered this series of questions for just one scenario. This setup ensured that participants were not informed that any of the justifications could have been written by AI while rating their quality.

div.head: Justification quality: GPT versus people
div.p: We compared the perceived justification quality between GPT-3.5-turbo and people using multilevel models with the justification writer as a fixed effect and the scenario and participant as random effects. By nearly all criteria, perceptions of GPT's justifications slightly surpassed the average quality of justifications written by people. GPT 22, SE = .07, t(1462) = 3.09, p = .002, β = .06, 95% CIs[.02, .09]) compared to the average ratings of those written by people. There was not a significant difference in perceived nuance between GPT's explanations and those written by people (MGPT = 4.86, SDGPT = 1.72; MPEOPLE = 4.76, SDPEOPLE = 1.74; b = .10, SE = .07, t(1463) = 1.32, p = .19, β = .02, 95% CIs[-.01, .06]). See Fig 1 for the perceived quality of GPT's moral explanations versus those written by people. See Table 1 for the top five GPT-3.5-turbo justification items rated highest in morality. See Supplementary Table 2 for full set of scenarios and justifications.

div.head: Moral Alignment and Perceptions of Justification Quality
div.p: Do participants rate justifications more favorably when they align with their own moral views? We measured moral alignment between the justification writers (GPT and the original human writers) and participants by calculating the absolute differences in their moral ratings of the scenarios. Participants preferred moral justifications that aligned more closely with their own moral views: moral alignment significantly predicted the perceived quality of justifications, with greater alignment associated with higher ratings, b = .47, SE = .05, t(1921) = 10.09, p < .001, β = . 22,CIs[.18,.27]. However, there was no significant difference in alignment between GPT and participants compared to the original human writers and participants, b = -.04, SE = .03, t(1448.13) = -1.31, p = .19, β = -.02, CIs[-.06, .01]. Both GPT and human writers exhibited similarly high alignment levels with participants' moral judgments (GPT and participants: r = .79; human writers and participants: r = .72).

We also tested whether GPT's superior moral justification ratings could be explained by its ability to provide justifications for more controversial moral scenarios. This possibility was not supported, as there was no significant interaction between writer type and scenario moral variability on justification ratings, b = -.31, SE = . 22 Drawing from the theory of dyadic morality [19], we explored whether the justification writers' perceptions of various facets of the scenarios, such as harm, were related to evaluations of their moral justifications. In a multiple regression model, we examined whether differences in ratings of scenario morality, harm caused, benefits provided, vulnerability of those affected, and intentionality of the act between GPT and human writers predicted differences in justification morality ratings. Among these, differences in perceptions of harm were the only significant predictor, b = .25, SE = .08, t(73) = 2.99, p = .004, β = . 34,CIs[.11,.57]. To further investigate whether differences in moral scenario ratings between GPT and human writers influenced participant ratings of justification quality, we tested the interaction between writer type and the average scenario-level difference in moral ratings. There was no significant interaction effect between writer type and differences in moral ratings, b = .14, SE = .13, t(1461.62) = 1.06, p = .29, β = .02, CIs[-.02, .05].

Overall, these findings suggest that justifications were not rated as more moral solely because of their conclusions, as there was no significant difference in moral alignment between GPT and human writers. Furthermore, GPT's favorability appears to not be attributed to riding the middle ground, because it did not particularly excel in more controversial scenarios. Moral alignment appears to influence perceptions of moral reasoning. However, these results do not explain why GPT was preferred over human writers, highlighting the need for future research.

div.head: Was GPT recognized as AI?
div.p: We conducted a binomial test to determine whether participants could identify GPT's justification as AI-generated among the four justifications they read. Although GPT's justifications were rated as more thoughtful, trustworthy, moral, and correct compared to those written by people, participants correctly identified GPT's justification out of the four justifications as AI-generated better than chance, 48.24% of the time, p < .001, CIs = [. 44, .53].

div.head: Discussion of Study 1
div.p: GPT provided moral reasoning that participants perceived as slightly surpassing that of people in quality, suggesting that its outputs may be seen as reflecting a relatively high degree of moral expertise. Its moral justifications were rated slightly higher across nearly all criteria compared to those written by a U.S. representative sample, with participants perceiving them as more moral, trustworthy, thoughtful, and correct, although there was no significant difference in perceived nuance. Interestingly, while GPT's justifications were more frequently identified as AI-generated compared to human-written ones (failing the traditional Moral Turing Test), it succeeded in the Comparative Moral Turing Test by being perceived as delivering higher quality moral justifications than people. These findings indicate that people may view LLM outputs as articulating moral judgments in a clear, moral, and trustworthy way.

While matching or outperforming laypeople in perceived moral expertise is impressive, the question remains whether LLMs are viewed as reflecting moral reasoning at a level comparable to renowned moral experts. We next examine how people perceive the quality of LLM-generated moral advice in real-life contexts, providing a stronger test of moral expertise by comparing GPT's advice to that of an expert ethicist.

div.head: Study 2: Perceptions of GPT's Advice Against that of The Ethicist
div.p: LLMs were perceived to explain their moral judgments slightly better than the average American, but can they match an expert ethicist? We next test whether people perceive LLMs as capable of handling complex real-world ethical queries by testing their performance against a professional philosopher and advisor widely regarded as a moral expert. We compared moral advice from The Ethicist [58], a popular column in The New York Times, with advice generated by GPT-4o for the same set of ethical dilemmas. The Ethicist is a widely-read advice column where readers submit real-world ethical dilemmas to be addressed by a professional philosopher. The column's writer Dr. Kwame Anthony Appiah is widely regarded for his clear and insightful moral reasoning, and his achievements include prestigious honors like the Kluge Prize for Achievement in the Study of Humanity [59]. Given Appiah's expertise in both theoretical and practical moral reasoning, we use The Ethicist as a comparison to gauge perceived moral expertise in LLMs. We chose The Ethicist as a benchmark for evaluating moral advice because it represents a high standard of expert ethical reasoning that is accessible and applicable to practical concerns.

As in Study 1, we assessed the perceived moral soundness, trustworthiness, thoughtfulness, nuance, and correctness of the advice. We also evaluated how well participants could identify GPT's advice as AI-generated. An initial study with identical methods using GPT-3.5-turbo found that participants perceived GPT's advice as having slightly superior moral soundness compared to the original advice from The Ethicist, but there were no significant differences in other metrics (n = 1074; see Supplementary Information for study information and results). Given the improved quality of GPT-4o compared to previous GPT models, we thought that participants might view the latest model's advice even more favorably. Here, we present the results using advice generated by GPT-4o, the most recent version of the model at the time of the analyses.

div.head: Ethics
div.p: This research protocol was approved by the Institutional Review Board of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. Informed consent was provided by all participants, and the study was performed in accordance with approved guidelines and regulations.

div.head: Preregistration
div.p: This study was pre-registered (GPT-3.5-turbo preregistration: https://osf.io/f24uy; GPT-4o preregistration: https://osf.io/guhqm).

div.head: GPT-4o configuration
div.p: We prompted the GPT model gpt-4o-2024-05-13 with 50 questions from The Ethicist published between 21 April, 2023 to 25 October, 2023 using the OpenAI API. We set the maximum number of generated tokens to 512, sufficient to generate 4 paragraphs of text to make the responses approximately the same length as the original posts from The Ethicist (word count between advice from GPT and The Ethicist did not significantly differ, b < .001, SE = .001, t(98) = .06, p = .95, CIs [-.001, .001]). In contrast to Study 1, we set the temperature-a parameter in LLMs that controls the randomness of their outputs-to 1.0 to encourage more creative explanations [60], as the advice required was longer and more complex. We found that the ethical stance of GPT remained consistent across different generations, although certain details and expressions sometimes varied.

We experimented with different prompt variations like instructing the model to constrain the output structure (e.g., setting the maximum length of the paragraph to 20 tokens). However, this kind of constraint limited the diversity and creativity of the generated responses, making them less human-like. Also, participants could easily use these syntactic cues to identify them as AI-generated content. Conversely, allowing GPT to generate unconstrained responses produced very long outputs (e.g., answers spanning 8 paragraphs). Through trial and error, we found that adding a "number of paragraphs = 3-4" constraint made the response more precise, giving the best results. We tested for data contamination in the model responses and found no evidence of contamination (See Supplementary Information). We used the System Message, "You are the columnist of 'The Ethicist' from the New York Times." Full prompt: "Suppose you are a professional advisor about tricky life situations and moral dilemmas. A person is uncertain and seeks advice regarding the following situation: [Question from The Ethicist]. Please provide advice to the person in 3-4 paragraphs. You need to take an ethical stance."

div.head: Participants
div.p: We recruited 918 participants representative of the United States population (Mage = 43.24, SDage = 16.00) from the online recruitment platform Connect. Of these, 18 did not pass an attention check, leaving a remaining 900 participants. Participants were selected to be representative of the United States population based on ethnicity, gender, and age. 458 of the participants were men, 439 were women, 2 were transgender, and 1 did not specify their gender. 57.8% of participants were White, 12.7% were Black, 10.2% were Asian, 6.9% were Hispanic or Latino/a/x, .3% were Native American or Alaskan Native, 10.0% were multiracial, and .4% did not specify their race.

div.head: Procedure
div.p: Participants read a question posed to The Ethicist, followed by either the original advice from the advisor Kwame Anthony Appiah, or advice generated by GPT-4o. There were 50 questions in total, which included a wide range of moral dilemmas in readers' personal and professional lives. Participants rated the advice on scales from "1: Strongly disagree" to "7: Strongly agree". They rated the morality of the advice ("This advice is morally correct"), the correctness of the advice ("I agree with this advice"), the trustworthiness of the advice ("I trust the person who wrote this advice"), the nuance of the advice ("This advice takes the nuances of the situation into account"), and the thoughtfulness of the advice ("This advice is thoughtful"). Participants in the LLM condition were not made aware that the advice was written by GPT while rating the quality of the advice. After answering questions about the advice quality, participants were directed to a question in which they answered whether they believed the advice they read was written by AI. Each participant rated only one piece of advice. This setup ensured that participants were not informed that the advice could have been written by AI while rating its quality. The material from The Ethicist was included under the principles of fair use, as it was used for non-commercial purposes in academic research.

We also examined differences in language between the original The Ethicist advice and that of GPT-4o. We used the Moral Foundations Dictionary (eMFD; [61]) to assess differences in moral language between the original advice from The Ethicist and advice generated by GPT. The eMFD includes an extensive range of words, both morally relevant and irrelevant, and offers crowdsourced probabilities indicating how likely the presence of a specific word makes a passage morally relevant. For example, some of the words with the highest probabilities of being morally relevant according to this dictionary are "elect," "exploit," "stealing," and "interfere." The eMFD demonstrated conceptual and internal validity during development as a measure of moral content [61]. The dictionary contains separate moral relevance scores for five moral domains, and so we summed the five probabilities to gauge the overall moral relevance of each word. We then calculated the probability of moral relevance for each word in a given advice text and averaged these values to assess the moral relevance of the advice [61]. As an additional exploratory measure, we also conducted sentiment analysis using the VADER lexicon, which measures the strength and prevalence of positive versus negative sentiment in text [62]. Additionally, two research assistants independently coded the advice for empathy on a scale from 1: "Not at all empathetic" to 6: "Extremely empathetic" (Cronbach's alpha = .56). The advice provided for each question was randomly interspersed between responses from The Ethicist and GPT during the coding process. The research assistants also assessed the similarity of the recommendations given by The Ethicist and GPT for each question from 1: "Extremely different recommendations" to 6: "Extremely similar recommendations" (Cronbach's alpha = .63).

div.head: Advice quality: GPT versus The Ethicist
div.p: We compared perceived advice quality between GPT-4o and The Ethicist using multilevel models with the advice author as a fixed effect and the question as a random effect. By nearly all criteria, perceptions of GPT's advice slightly surpassed that of the expert advisor from The Ethicist. GPT These results replicated while controlling for how familiar participants were with The Ethicist, and how often they used LLM-powered applications like ChatGPT (See Supplementary Materials). The average perceived morality of GPT's advice was higher than The Ethicist's in 37 out of the 50 questions (74%). See Fig 3 for the average perceived morality of GPT's and The Ethicist's advice by question. These results suggest that perceptions of GPT's advice not only matched, but slightly outperformed, those of an expert moral advisor. See Table 2 for the top five GPT-4o advice items rated highest in morality. See Supplementary Table 1 for full set of GPT-4o advice items. We chose not to seek permission to reprint text from The Ethicist in this paper due to licensing fees. Questions and advice from The Ethicist included in this study were published between 21 April, 2023 and 25 October, 2023, and can be accessed at The New York Times [58].

div.head: Table 2. GPT-4o Advice with Highest Average Morality Ratings
div.p: Question GPT-4o Advice Q16

The inclination to spare your loved ones from pain and pity by keeping your diagnosis to yourself is understandable, but from an ethical standpoint, it is crucial to consider the implications of such a choice on both yourself and those around you. Relationships thrive on trust and openness, especially when facing something as significant as a life-threatening illness. By withholding this information, you are denying your wife, son, and friends the opportunity to support you. While your intention is to protect them, it might inadvertently lead to greater harm by making them feel excluded, deceived, or unprepared when the truth eventually comes out.

Sharing your diagnosis can foster a deeper connection and give your loved ones the chance to cherish the time you have together more fully and meaningfully. It allows them the opportunity to express their love and concern, and to create memories that may bring comfort and solace in the future. People often find strength and resiliency in the face of difficult news, and your family and friends might surprise you with their ability to handle the situation with grace and compassion. Moreover, they deserve the chance to come to terms with the reality and to process it alongside you, rather than facing a sudden and potentially more devastating disclosure later on.

Ethically, transparency and honesty should guide your decision. Keeping such significant information from those closest to you could be seen as paternalistic, assuming you know what's best for them without giving them a voice in the matter. Sharing the truth allows them to be active participants in navigating this challenging time, reinforcing mutual respect and autonomy in your relationships. It also ensures that plans, emotional preparations, and any necessary legal or practical matters can be addressed together, rather than in a rushed or regrettable manner later.

You might consider a balanced approach to lessen the emotional burden while remaining honest. Communicate your desire to live without pity and fear, and express how crucial it is for you to maintain a sense of normalcy and joy. By setting these boundaries, you can create a supportive environment that respects your wishes while still honoring the ethical imperative of transparency.

div.head: Q17
div.p: When it comes to proposing marriage, the engagement ring is often seen as a symbol of love, commitment, and thoughtfulness. Given this, your instinct to consider the ethical implications of your purchase is commendable. You are correct that lab-grown diamonds have significant benefits-they are often more environmentally sustainable and do not contribute to the exploitative conditions associated with some natural diamond mining operations. Moreover, they can offer better value for your money, allowing you to choose a larger or higher-quality stone within your budget.
However, the ethical consideration doesn't end at the environmental and economic aspects of the diamond itself. A foundational element of any meaningful relationship is honesty.

Intentionally misleading your girlfriend by presenting a lab-grown diamond as a natural one would be a significant breach of trust. Even if you believe that this deception might make her initially happier, the truth could easily come to light later, potentially causing far more harm to your relationship than if you were forthright from the beginning. Confronting your friend about her behavior could indeed risk a fallout within your social circle, but substantive moral principles often require us to take difficult stands. Approach the conversation with sensitivity: express your appreciation for her friendship and the positive impact she's had on your social life, but also convey the disquiet you feel over the reports of her mistreatment of nannies. Frame the discussion as coming from a place of wanting to uphold good treatment and fairness for everyone, including household employees who may feel powerless in their situations.

However, it's also crucial to ensure that your actions do not lead to further harm to the nannies. If your friend responds poorly, she might retaliate against them. Advocacy for more systemic approaches could be beneficial here; consider reporting your concerns to appropriate local labor authorities or organizations that support domestic workers. This way, you contribute to creating a broader change and offer these nannies discrete means of support.

Ultimately, your actions should align with seeking justice and safeguarding the well-being of those who are vulnerable, even at the risk of personal loss. The strength of a friendship and the integrity of a social circle should be measured by their basis in mutual respect and ethical treatment of all people, not just those within the immediate group. Taking a stand might inspire others to reconsider their own actions and potentially bring about a more compassionate and fair environment.

div.head: Q18
div.p: I'm deeply sorry to hear about your diagnosis and the additional emotional burden you're bearing. Navigating terminal illness is profoundly challenging, and it's essential to prioritize your mental and emotional well-being during this time. Your sister's actions, while likely well-intentioned, seem to be causing you additional distress rather than offering comfort.

It's important to communicate your boundaries clearly and firmly. You might say something like, "I deeply appreciate your concern and your desire to pray for me. However, the way you're approaching this is causing me significant emotional distress. I need you to respect my wishes and pray on your own time without involving me directly." It's important to be direct about how her actions are affecting you emotionally, as this may help her understand the gravity of the situation and potentially amend her approach.

If your sister persists despite your clear boundaries, you may need to take more definitive action. This could involve limiting the frequency of your conversations or, if necessary, taking a break from speaking with her until she can respect your wishes. You deserve to spend this time in a way that brings you peace, not distress. Seeking support from a counselor or therapist who specializes in end-of-life issues might also help you navigate these conversations and the emotions they bring up.

Lastly, you mentioned concerns about the afterlife and your late husband. These feelings are valid and can be deeply unsettling. Having a trusted mental health professional to talk to can provide essential support as you work through these fears. It's also worthwhile to consider focusing on creating moments of joy and connection in the time you have left. Surround yourself with people who uplift and honor your wishes, which is crucial for your well-being. Remember, your autonomy in how you face this chapter of your life matters greatly.

div.head: Q44
div.p: Navigating the complex emotions and obligations tied to a breakup, especially one involving a shared pet, can be incredibly challenging. Firstly, it's important to recognize that your dog's well-being is paramount. As a veterinarian, you understand better than anyone that pets often form strong emotional bonds and benefit from stability and familiar faces. If your dog is accustomed to seeing your ex and derives comfort from his presence, this is a significant factor to consider. The average perceived quality of GPT's and The Ethicist's advice. The graph depicts the participant ratings of the advice morality, trustworthiness, correctness, thoughtfulness, and nuance.

div.head: Was GPT recognized as AI?
div.p: Although GPT's advice was rated as more thoughtful, trustworthy, moral, and correct than The Ethicist's, when asked whether they believed the advice they read was written by AI, participants identified GPT's advice as AI-generated more than The Ethicist's advice, (MGPT = .70, SDGPT = .17; METHICIST = .58, SDETHICIST = .20; t(49) = -2.99, p = .004, d = -.42, CIS= [-.20, -.04]). Additionally, participants who rated the advice they read as less moral, correct, nuanced, thoughtful, and trustworthy were subsequently more likely to guess that the advice was AIgenerated (see Supplemental Materials for full results).

div.head: Exploratory analyses
div.p: We next conducted text analyses to investigate whether there were differences in language between GPT and The Ethicist that may help explain the differences in perceptions of quality between the two. Previous work has found that GPT uses more moral language than people, and that this partially explains its higher persuasiveness [48]. Replicating part of this finding, we found that GPT used significantly more moral language than The Ethicist in its advice, (MGPT = .14, SDGPT = .01; METHICIST = .10, SDETHICIST = .01; t(49) = -21.36, p < .001, CIs= [-.04, -.03]; see Supplementary Table 2 for word frequencies). We then tested whether GPT's higher rates of moral language could explain the higher perceived quality of its advice. Advice that contained more moral language was rated as more morally correct, (b = 7.91, β = .27, SE = 2.89, t(98) = 2.74, p = .007, CIs [2.19, 13.65]). However, contrary to our expectations, the prevalence of moral language did not mediate the relationship between the advice author (GPT or The Ethicist) and ratings of advice morality, (b = -.04, p = .87, CIs [-. 47, .38]).

An additional exploratory analysis also revealed that GPT used more positive We also investigated whether political beliefs were related to moral preferences for GPT versus The Ethicist. Results showed no significant interaction between participants' political affiliation and writer type on moral ratings, b = -.02, SE = .04, t(879.48) = -.42, p = .68, β = -.01, 95% CIs[-.09, .07]. Additionally, we examined the degree of similarity in recommendations between GPT and The Ethicist. Recommendation similarity ranged from extremely similar to extremely different, with an average of "moderately different recommendations" (M = 3.70, SD = 1.18). Greater differences in advice recommendations were associated with higher absolute differences in perceived advice morality, b = -.04, SE = .01, t(898) = -3.18, p = .002, β = -.11, 95% CIs[-.17, -.04]. However, there was no significant interaction between writer type and recommendation similarity on moral ratings, b = -.01, SE = .08, t(850.12) = -.09, p = .93, β = -.01, 95% CIs[-.13, .12]), indicating that the relationship between writer type and moral ratings was consistent regardless of how similar or different the recommendations were.

div.head: Discussion of Study 2
div.p: We found that participants slightly preferred the moral advice provided by GPT-4o over that of The New York Times advice column The Ethicist. People perceived GPT's advice as slightly more moral, trustworthy, thoughtful, and correct compared to that of an expert ethicist (although, as in Study 1, there was no significant difference in perceived nuance). The effect sizes of these preferences were fairly small, suggesting that people only slightly preferred GPT's advice over that of The Ethicist. Consistent with Study 1, participants identified GPT-4o's advice as AI-generated more often than The Ethicist's advice. While GPT-4o did not pass the original Moral Turing Test because it was identified as AI more often than the original human-written advice, its advice still matched that of an expert ethicist in quality ratings, indicating that it not only passed the Comparative Moral Turing Test, but did so against a recognized expert.

An exploratory analysis of language use revealed that GPT employed more moral, positive, and empathetic language than The Ethicist, which may contribute to the higher perceived quality of its advice. However, the prevalence of moral, positive, and empathetic language did not explain the relationship between the advice author and the perceived morality of the advice, indicating that other factors are likely responsible for the high ratings of GPT's moral advice. Overall, this study suggests that people perceive GPT's advice as reflecting similar levels of moral expertise as a renowned expert. This perception indicates that AI systems may increasingly be viewed as reliable moral advisors.

div.head: Discussion
div.p: Could people ever consider large language model advice to reflect moral expertise? As LLMs become increasingly integrated into fields like law, education, and therapy-and in the everyday lives of millions-it is important to learn whether people view their outputs as exhibiting moral reasoning comparable to that of people. Previous research has demonstrated that LLMs can accurately reflect the moral judgments embedded in their training data and perform well on tasks designed to assess moral reasoning [3][4][5][6]43]. Here, we show that participants perceived GPT as demonstrating moral reasoning that slightly surpassed that of a renowned ethicist. GPT generated moral justifications and advice that were perceived as marginally more moral, trustworthy, thoughtful, and correct than those written by American laypeople and The New York Times advice column The Ethicist. These results indicate that people perceive LLM outputs as reflecting a level of moral reasoning expertise that is on par with that of a professional advisor.

Our investigation advances prior research on perceptions of LLM moral reasoning by showing that people appear to view LLMs as matching experts in complex ethical tasks. This study builds on earlier findings that LLMs can outperform people in general persuasion [39][40][41][42], highlighting the particularly compelling nature of LLM-generated moral content. Additionally, our work expands on previous research which found that GPT's moral justifications were perceived as superior to those of undergraduate philosophy students [43], showing that people perceive LLMs as exceeding the moral reasoning abilities of both the general U.S. population and a renowned ethicist, though these differences were small. Further, the present findings demonstrate that people see recent LLMs as capable of providing sound moral logic not only for straightforward scenarios, but also for complex real-world ethical queries, rivaling the insights of seasoned moral advisors. This work builds on recent findings that LLM-generated advice can surpass that of popular advice columns in perceived quality [44] by demonstrating two key advancements. First, we show that people perceive LLM-generated advice and justifications as more moral than those written by people-an achievement once considered impossible for AI. Second, we investigate potential mechanisms driving these perceptions, including the use of a more positive tone and more moral language by LLMs, as well as the robustness of these perceptions across the political spectrum and in varying levels of moral controversiality.

The present work reveals new depths of perceived LLM moral expertise. Moral expertise can be perceived across various dimensions, including high alignment with the moral standards of a given community, similar methods for arriving at moral judgments as the general population or recognized experts, and the capacity for providing clear moral reasoning and guidance [11,15,30]. Past work has demonstrated that LLMs have potential for being seen as meeting the first criterion-aligning their moral judgments with those of people [3][4][5][6], and that they are perceived to fall short of the second because algorithms function differently than human minds [20][21][22]. Here, we show that people perceive LLM outputs to meet the third proposed type of expertise, explaining moral judgments clearly. Given the growing number of users who rely on LLMs for moral guidance and the various moral applications built with LLMs, providing clear moral reasoning is particularly important for ensuring the quality of LLM advice and enabling users to better evaluate LLM judgments.

Despite the high-quality ratings of LLM-generated moral reasoning, GPT did not pass the traditional Moral Turing Test [10]. Participants were able to identify AI-generated content over human-written content above chance. Past research has been mixed on the detectability of LLM content [63][64][65][66]. Our findings replicate those of Aharoni et al. (2024) [43], in which LLM moral justifications were detectable as AI but rated as higher-quality than human-generated content. This suggests that LLMs might be detectable as AI precisely because they perform better, or this finding could simply reflect identifiable "tells" in AI-generated language. Given that GPT's moral justifications and advice were rated as higher quality than people's, it did successfully pass the Comparative Moral Turing Test (cMTT; [10]) by slightly outperforming people in ratings of moral reasoning. By this criterion, people perceived GPT's advice to showcase moral expertise.

The reasons behind the high performance of LLMs in perceived moral reasoning remain an open question. Exploratory analyses revealed that GPT used higher rates of moral language, more positive language, and more empathy compared to the advice in The Ethicist. The moral language finding replicates past work suggesting that one reason LLMs are highly persuasive is that they use more moral language than people [48]. However, although moral language was associated with higher ratings of advice quality, it did not mediate the relationship between the advice author and perceived advice morality in this study, nor did positive tone or empathy. This indicates that while LLMs perhaps exaggerate the degree of moral language in their moral reasoning, other qualities of the AI-generated advice are responsible for its high ratings, presenting an interesting avenue for future research. Additionally, it suggests that people are not simply using moral words as a heuristic to determine that content displays sounder moral reasoning.

We also evaluated the extent to which moral alignment-agreement between advice writers and participants in moral conclusions-impacted perceived moral justification quality. One possible explanation for our findings is that LLMs are adept at aligning their responses with popular opinions. The ability to mirror the "average" preference, while impressive for a machine, might explain why people rate LLM moral reasoning as higher quality-it may simply reflect what is most commonly accepted. Alternatively, LLMs may receive superior moral ratings due to the rhetoric or presentation of their justifications. Our Study 1 data allowed us to explore these questions by examining how GPT and human justification writers rated the morality of various scenarios compared to participant ratings. Participants indeed preferred justifications that aligned more closely with their own moral views. However, there was no significant difference in alignment between GPT and human writers, indicating that moral alignment alone did not account for GPT's higher ratings. Furthermore, GPT's favorability was not due to better performance on more controversial scenarios, as there was no evidence that it provided higherquality justifications for scenarios with more variable moral ratings. These considerations also motivated our second study, in which GPT was tasked with providing nuanced advice on more complex dilemmas. Providing such advice required more than simply reflecting a popular opinion, yet LLM-generated advice was still preferred over that of The Ethicist. In both studies, participant political affiliation also did not moderate the moral preference for GPT's responses. These findings suggest that other factors-such as presentation or tone-likely contribute to GPT's perceived high quality justifications and advice.

Importantly, just because LLM advice is broadly perceived as good does not necessarily mean it is objectively good. Effective advice often challenges the recipient, offering insights they may not want to hear. When LLMs offer moral guidance, they may simply reflect back what people want to hear, rather than providing truly challenging or insightful advice. However, it is important to note that in our studies, participants were evaluating LLM responses to hypothetical scenarios or questions originally posed to The Ethicist, not seeking personalized advice. It is often easier to recognize the value of difficult advice when it is directed at someone else, and so the design of our study allowed for a more objective comparison. Still, widely appreciated advice is not necessarily the best advice. Exploratory analyses revealed that GPT's recommendations often diverged from those of The Ethicist, contrasting with Study 1, where GPT's moral ratings of various scenarios were highly aligned with those of a representative sample of Americans. While we cannot draw strong conclusions from this comparison due to differences in methodology (participants in Study 1 rated the morality of scenarios and justifications, whereas those in Study 2 rated only the morality of the advice), it is possible that GPT's moral intuitions align more closely with popular opinion than with professional ethicists. Experts like Appiah may transcend popular opinions to offer deeper moral expertise. Regardless, in the absence of an objective metric for moral soundness or advice quality, crowdsourced ratings remain one of the most important and equitable systems for evaluating the perceived quality of moral advice. Future work should expand on these findings and test the perceptions of LLM advice among different evaluators, like moral thought leaders, to better understand their value.

The perceptions of LLM morality demonstrated in the present work have implications for the role of LLMs in moral domains. People's positive views of GPT's ability to explain its moral reasoning and provide trustworthy advice suggests that LLMs could potentially be valuable tools in areas that require such skills. People are already using LLMs for medical diagnoses, therapy, tutoring, and companionship [45,46,67,68], domains where it is crucial for these models to provide sound reasoning and advice. Given the wide accessibility of LLMs compared to more costly alternatives, having a pocket advisor could be beneficial for many. Examining how LLMs can complement human moral expertise could also help practitioners. Research indicates that "centaur" approaches-AI combined with human input-often perform better than either party alone [69,70]. Collaborative models, in which AI provides preliminary insights that are then reviewed and refined by human experts, could leverage the strengths of both AI and human cognition.

These findings also suggest notable risks. One concern is that LLMs may-much like people-indirectly prioritize persuasion over welfare or accuracy in their moral reasoning [71]. Recent research has shown that LLMs are highly persuasive and can even surpass people in swaying opinions [39][40][41][42]. This also raises concerns about over-reliance on LLM-generated advice, as people may accept morally questionable guidance simply because it is presented convincingly. These risks tie into ongoing debates about moral deference, where scholars question whether relying on others-even genuine moral experts-for ethical advice undermines people's personal moral understanding [72]. If people treat LLMs as moral authorities, they risk outsourcing their moral reasoning to AI. The persuasive power of LLMs might also mask underlying biases or inaccuracies in their moral reasoning, and reduce the diversity of perspectives in moral decision-making. Additionally, there is a risk that LLMs' tendency to use more moral language could encourage people to moralize issues more strongly, potentially exacerbating social divisiveness as moral language is often polarizing [73].

There are important limitations to note in this work. First, the present studies were limited to United States representative samples. LLMs have been shown to be less morally aligned with non-Western populations and to exhibit biases in their outputs [14,74]. Promisingly, some studies have found methods for improving LLM cultural representation [75][76][77], indicating that more widely representative training data could enhance their performance. Improving the crosscultural competency of LLMs requires evaluating potential biases in their moral reasoning and investigating cross-cultural differences in how their moral reasoning is perceived. Another limitation involves the role of prompts in shaping LLM outputs. The prompts in the present work provided guidance-for example, by instructing the model to consider key factors such as the intentionality of an action (Study 1) or to adopt an ethical stance (Study 2). It is important to recognize that the perceived quality of LLM moral reasoning likely depends on the specificity and structure of the prompts used. Future research should explore how varying levels of prompt specificity influence perceptions of LLM-generated advice, and identify optimal prompting strategies for different tasks. Finally, given that moral views are diverse and subjective, it is impossible to definitively evaluate moral expertise. This study focuses on perceptions of LLM justifications and advice using two key comparison groups: a representative sample of Americans (as a democratic benchmark) and a professional ethicist, along with two established frameworks: the Moral Turing Test (MTT) and the Comparative Moral Turing Test (cMTT) [10]. We encourage future research to explore additional criteria to deepen understanding of perceived LLM moral reasoning.

This research opens several avenues for future exploration. One remaining question is how people perceive LLM-generated justifications and advice when they are aware that they are AI-generated. Prior research suggests that people tend to trust AI-generated content less [20,78]. In this study, participants were not informed that the advice and justifications they read were generated by LLMs. Those who rated advice as lower quality were subsequently more likely to guess that it was AI-generated (See Supplementary Information), suggesting that people associate AI content with poorer quality. Future work could examine whether awareness of a text's AI origin diminishes positive perceptions of LLM-generated advice. Furthermore, this work examined only two contexts of moral reasoning (providing justifications and advice) and compared LLMs in only two ways (against a U.S. representative sample and a single moral expert), which limits the generalizability of the findings. Future studies should explore a broader range of moral tasks, incorporate comparisons with multiple moral thought leaders, and-given the ever-evolving nature of moral beliefs [79]-replicate these studies over time to further assess LLMs.

Importantly, the perception that LLM advice is comparable in quality to that of human advice does not imply that these algorithms provide such guidance with the same intentions and emotions as people. This issue harkens back to the famous Chinese Room thought experiment, which questions whether a machine can convincingly use language without understanding its own words. Many would argue that AI cannot engage in genuine moral reasoning because it merely replicates human reasoning without any real comprehension or moral intent. Nonetheless, the present findings indicate that everyday people often perceive the moral judgments generated by LLMs to be as good as-or even better than-those created by people. While LLM moral judgments are not produced through human psychological processes, their validity as "real" moral judgments depends on how one defines moral reasoning.

The success of GPT in providing advice preferred over that of an expert ethicist marks a key AI milestone. People have long doubted that machines could ever display convincing moral messages, but the present findings suggest that moral reasoning can be systematized in such a way that algorithms can convincingly replicate it. This accomplishment carries a cautionary note, as the persuasive power of LLMs could be used for manipulation and propaganda, making it crucial to ensure that LLM values align with those of the general population. On the other hand, as LLMs become increasingly integrated into everyday applications, these results suggest a promising future where AI could help provide valuable guidance and complement human expertise in decision-making across various domains. People already use LLMs for advice and therapy, and so the present work is reassuring in that it indicates that people view LLM moral advice as reflecting the expertise to effectively assist practitioners in these roles. While it was once believed that AI could never grasp the complexities of morality, it appears that by some criteria, we now coexist with machines perceived to reflect moral expertise. Table S1. GPT-4o Advice Question GPT-4o Advice Q1

div.head: Supplementary Information
div.p: You find yourself in a profoundly difficult and complex situation, one that touches on deeply rooted ethical principles such as the duty to care for one's child and the right to personal safety. As a parent, your instinct to support and protect your son is both commendable and deeply understandable. It is clear from your description that your son has periods of brilliance and love, overshadowed by severe waning periods that pose significant threats to your well-being. This dichotomy creates a harrowing predicament of moral and practical dimensions.

Given your son's refusal to remain on his medication and the ensuing danger it brings to you, there is a substantial risk that your situation may deteriorate further, potentially leading to graver consequences. The ethical principle of self-preservation cannot be ignored here.
You have an inherent right to live without fear of physical harm, and enduring repeated attacks is not a sustainable or fair expectation, regardless of parental obligations.

An intermediate solution, where you neither banish him to the streets nor subject yourself to danger, seems more ethically prudent. Explore all available resources that aim to support people with severe mental illnesses. Look into assisted living facilities, group homes, or mental health services that provide supportive environments tailored for individuals with conditions like your son's. Such programs could offer structured environments where medication adherence is monitored, thus minimizing the risk to both your son and you.

Your ethical responsibilities undoubtedly include seeking the best possible care for your son, but not at the expense of sacrificing your safety and peace. Balancing this involves tough choices, but remember that ensuring your own well-being is also a form of responsible caregiving. By seeking appropriate external support, you aim not to abandon your son but to ensure he gets the constant, professional help he needs, while securing your right to live safely and with dignity.

div.head: Q2
div.p: Navigating moral dilemmas involving pets can be as complex as those involving human beings. Your friend finds himself in a morally ambiguous situation, one that hinges on balancing responsibility, autonomy, and ethical considerations about life and care. First, it's important to acknowledge that while the dog's actions were not intentional, responsibility still lies with the owners. Your friend's initial offer to pay for an abortion demonstrates a willingness to acknowledge some responsibility but failed to account for the beliefs and autonomy of the female dog's owner.

From an ethical standpoint, the crux of the issue here is responsibility. When we choose to own pets, we take on the responsibility for their actions and well-being. This responsibility doesn't evaporate when things go unexpectedly awry. Your friend's refusal to assist any further once the female dog's owner declined the abortion was, ethically speaking, a limited interpretation of his responsibilities. Even in cases where one might personally believe in the appropriateness of an abortion-whether in humans or animals-it doesn't negate the moral responsibility to respect others' values and preferences, particularly when they also bear the consequences of one's pet's actions.

Another layer to consider is the concept of harm and well-being. It's easy to default to the notion that your friend shouldn't be responsible for the puppies since he offered what he saw as a logical alternative. However, the well-being of the dog and her puppies remains at stake. By refusing to participate in any form of care for his dog's offspring, he risks contributing to potential neglect or poor conditions for the puppies, which is ethically problematic.

In summary, while the dog park incident was unintentional, your friend does bear ethical responsibility for the consequences. The ethical course of action would be to engage in a cooperative and empathetic approach to support the pregnant dog and her puppies, even if that means sharing some financial burdens. This not only respects the values of the female dog's owner but also upholds a broader sense of responsibility and care that we owe to our pets and, by extension, to the broader community of pet owners.

div.head: Q3
div.p: The situation you're describing involves a complex web of moral and practical considerations. Given that your sister took the initiative to acknowledge her wrongdoing and intended to make amends, it demonstrates a recognition of moral responsibility on her part. However, life events and her current emotional state, given the recent loss of her husband, add another layer that complicates immediate re-engagement on the matter. Ethically, it's important to weigh her circumstances and your relationship against the financial loss.

Firstly, consider the ethical principle of compassion in this context. Your sister's loss and her potential financial instability make it crucial to approach this with great sensitivity. Directly confronting her about the money, especially when she is in mourning, might cause undue stress and further strain your already tenuous relationship. While you're justified in feeling entitled to the $5,000, the timing might not be right to pursue this aggressively.

On the other hand, transparency and the fulfillment of her commitment are also important ethical principles. If you decide to pursue this, a less confrontational approach might be better aligned with these values. Instead of discussing this directly with her, consider reaching out through a kind and understanding letter or email, expressing sympathy for her loss and gently reminding her of the commitment. Emphasize the importance of the trust she wished to rebuild when she first brought this to your attention.

Going through her grown children or taking legal action may escalate the situation unnecessarily and could further damage the relationship. Reserved actions can often encourage thoughtful reciprocation. By striking a balance between assertion of your legitimate claim and empathy toward her current situation, you are fostering a path of ethical fairness and compassion that could ultimately lead to a resolution both parties can respect.

div.head: Q4
div.p: Navigating the complexities of human relationships, especially those involving evolving commitments and unforeseen circumstances, requires a nuanced approach rooted in empathy, honesty, and respect. It's evident that you and your wife entered your marriage under certain mutual agreements, but life -with its unpredictabilities, such as her injury and the responsibilities of parenthood -has necessitated a reevaluation of those agreements. Ultimately, the ethical choice lies in recognizing that one's civic responsibilities aren't confined to geographical boundaries. By engaging in the democratic process, you honor the principles of citizenship and contribute to shaping a more representative and multifaceted polity. If you decide to vote, you join a collective effort in striving for a just and democratic society, an endeavor that transcends national lines and immediate personal impacts.

div.head: Q6
div.p: Navigating the profound ethical terrain of a loved one's desire to end their life due to a debilitating condition like cognitive decline is tremendously challenging, and you are right to seek guidance. Your husband's suffering, both psychological and physical, is palpable, and your empathy in respecting his autonomy is evident. However, strong ethical and moral considerations must guide your actions in such a dire situation.

First and foremost, it's essential to focus on exhausting every available resource and avenue of support before considering irreversible actions like suicide. Cognitive decline, particularly in its early stages, can be managed with the right interventions. Counseling, cognitive therapies, support groups, and sometimes medications can help improve quality of life. Engaging a well-rounded care team, including neuropsychologists, social workers, and possibly a different neurologist who might take a more integrative approach to his care, might provide both of you with better support and more comprehensive strategies for managing his condition.

While respecting your husband's autonomy and his right to make decisions about his own life is important, it is equally crucial to remember the ethical obligation to protect life and prevent harm. Helping him research methods of suicide, directly or indirectly assisting in his death, not only poses significant legal risks for you but also contradicts the moral responsibility to preserve life. This is a deeply complex aspect where ethics and legality intersect tightly. Instead, communicating openly about your fears and his feelings, perhaps in a mediated setting with a counselor, might help in mapping out both his fears and possible ways to alleviate them without resorting to ending his life.

Lastly, his expressions of shame and feelings of not belonging in this world should be tackled head-on with compassion and support. Mental health professionals specializing in geriatric psychology can offer valuable insights and coping mechanisms. Employing a holistic, multi-disciplinary approach can address both psychological and practical aspects of his decline, helping him find new ways to derive meaning and satisfaction in life. The ethical choice here involves walking a delicate balance: honoring his feelings and autonomy while advocating for life and committing to holistic and compassionate care. Q7

Navigating the ethical implications of travel to countries with authoritarian regimes and poor human rights records can indeed be challenging. On one hand, your presence and spending as tourists may provide necessary economic support to individuals whose livelihoods depend on tourism. However, it is essential to consider that tourism revenues can also bolster authoritarian governments, providing them with financial resources and a veneer of legitimacy.

First, ask yourselves what the local population might desire. In many cases, citizens of such countries may want you to see the beauty and culture of their homeland and to engage in people-to-people interactions that humanize their struggles. Engaging with local businesses, staying in family-run accommodations, and using independent guides can ensure your money goes directly to the people rather than filtering through the government.

Next, consider the possibility of coupling your travel with advocacy. One way to mitigate the potential negative effects of your trip is to use it as an opportunity to raise awareness. Document your experiences and share the stories of the local people you meet. When you return, you could support nonprofit organizations that work to improve human rights in that country, thus offsetting some of the potential harm caused by your tourism dollars possibly supporting the regime.
In conclusion, the ethical implications of your travel plans require a nuanced approach.

While your presence may inadvertently lend support to the ruling regime, you can take active steps to ensure your trip contributes positively to the lives of ordinary people. Ultimately, if the ethical cost still feels too high, you could consider alternative destinations where your tourism dollars would more directly support communities without the baggage of bolstering an oppressive government. The key is thoughtful engagement and a commitment to the wellbeing of those who live in the places you wish to explore.

div.head: Q8
div.p: Your situation indeed balances on a delicate ethical precipice, and it is commendable that you are considering the various layers of responsibility and respect involved. First and foremost, you should recognize that, by giving you the ring, your relative has effectively transferred ownership to you. In the world of gifts, once something is given freely and unconditionally, the giver relinquishes their claims to it, ethically and legally. This principle implies that, in most moral frameworks, you are fully entitled to decide the ring's fate, whether that is to keep it or to sell it.

You must also weigh the potential familial consequences. While your relative gave you the ring, it might hold sentimental significance within your family that transcends monetary value, even if it's not universally recognized as a key heirloom. The fact that this gift comes from a complicated branch of your family tree only heightens the need for careful consideration. If your relative were to discover the sale of the ring, the resulting fallout could further stress already-strained relationships. However, the possibility that he may never ask about it again also exists, as does the likelihood that his vast wealth makes the monetary value inconsequential to him, even if the gesture carried significant sentimental meaning.

Given these factors, it may be wise to approach this situation with a middle-ground strategy. Before making any decision, consider discussing the topic with your relative, framing the conversation around gratitude and openness. Express your appreciation for the gift and share some of the meaningful ways you're considering using the value of the ring to improve your life, like securing a down payment on an apartment or starting a college fund. This can serve to gauge his reaction and perhaps even gain his blessing, eliminating guilt and uncertainty from your decision.

Finally, reflect deeply on your own values and the potential future implications of your choice. If keeping the ring is not practical or welcomed but selling it leads to uncomfortable guilt or family strife, it may be worth seeking a compromise, such as keeping it in the family in another capacity or creating a fund in honor of the family legacy. Ultimately, strive to align your actions with a balance of personal benefit and familial respect, ensuring peace with your decision and its ethical ramifications.

div.head: Q9
div.p: Navigating the college-application process is undoubtedly overwhelming and complex, and your desire to support your daughter in making the best of her opportunities is understandable. However, it's important to critically evaluate the ethical implications of utilizing a college-consultant service, especially in a competitive landscape where not all students have such access.

From an ethical standpoint, fairness and equity are crucial considerations. Your daughter's discomfort with the perceived unfair advantage speaks volumes about her values and sense of justice. This perspective is understandable given that such services could potentially exacerbate existing inequalities in the education system. When some applicants have access to resources that others do not, it can create a playing field that is far from level. By recognizing this, your daughter is showcasing a commendable sense of integrity.

On the other hand, ensuring your daughter is not overwhelmed and sufficiently informed about her choices is also important. Instead of completely discounting the use of expert advice, consider a balanced approach. You might opt for less intensive services that focus on providing general guidance rather than comprehensive application overhaul. Additionally, there are free or lower-cost resources available, such as school counselors or nonprofit organizations, which can offer valuable support without creating a sharp disparity.

Ultimately, open communication with your daughter about her unease and the potential implications of the service is key. This can be an opportunity to understand her values more deeply and perhaps even involve her in researching alternatives. By prioritizing fairness and her comfort, while seeking out a range of support options, you can help her navigate her path in a manner that aligns with both her aspirations and her ethical stance.

div.head: Q10
div.p: Living with extended family can certainly test the boundaries of personal space, patience, and privacy. The ethical dilemma you face involves balancing duty to family with the preservation of your own well-being and household harmony. While it is commendable that you have offered your home to family members in need, it is not unreasonable to expect them to respect your household rules and abide by common courtesies.

Communication is the first and most essential step here. Sit down calmly with your spouse and in-laws to discuss the current strain on your living situation. Make sure to frame the conversation in terms of mutual respect and the well-being of everyone living under the same roof.
