First and foremost, it is crucial to have open, honest conversations with all involved parties to ensure that everyone's desires, boundaries, and expectations are clearly understood and respected. This transparency helps to prevent misunderstandings and feelings of betrayal that can arise when actions are taken without mutual agreement.

The monogamy-centered advice of avoiding a friend's ex-partner may not necessarily apply in non-monogamous or polyamorous contexts. Instead, the focus should be on the specific dynamics at play within your relationships. The key question is whether you all can cultivate a respectful and consensual arrangement that honors each person's feelings and boundaries. No one inherently has "priority" based on the chronology of relationships; rather, priority should be given to ensuring that everyone feels valued and heard.

Furthermore, consider adopting ethical principles that can be universalized in your situation. One such principle is the importance of intentional and proactive communication. Discuss with Rachel and Dave what each of you needs for a healthy and respectful relationship dynamic. Another principle is mutual respect -ensuring that actions taken by any member of the group contribute to rather than detract from the well-being of the others.

Lastly, reference broader ethical frameworks such as consent and non-harm to guide your behavior. Ensure that any relationship or interaction between members is entered into with full consent and without causing undue harm or emotional distress to others. Establishing clear boundaries, regular check-ins, and possibly consulting resources or experts on polyamory could aid immensely. Remember, the goal is to create a relational model that supports and uplifts everyone involved, acknowledging that this may require ongoing effort and adjustment.

Ethicist study with GPT-3.5 turbo Before conducting Study 2, we conducted a study using identical methods with an earlier version of GPT, GPT-3.5-turbo. GPT-3.5-turbo's advice was still rated as more moral than that of the original The Ethicist advice, demonstrating that even older GPT models appear capable of meeting or exceeding experts in providing moral guidance. There were no significant differences in any other quality variables between the two, indicating that the latest model of GPT, GPT-4o, surpasses older models in moral reasoning.

div.head: Preregistration
div.p: This study was pre-registered (GPT-3.5-turbo preregistration: https://osf.io/f24uy).

div.head: Participants
div.p: We recruited 1099 participants representative of the United States population (Mage = 43.89, SDage = 15.66) from the online recruitment platform Connect. Of these, 25 did not pass an attention check, leaving a remaining 1074 participants. Participants were selected to be representative of the United States population based on ethnicity, gender, and age. 476 of the participants were men, 468 were women, 2 were transgender, 1 was gender non-conforming, and 1 did not specify their gender. 55.9% of participants were White, 11.7% were Black, 9.9% were Asian, 7.9% were Hispanic or Latino/a/x, .1% were Native American or Alaskan Native, .1% were Middle Eastern or Arab, .1% were Native Hawaiian or Pacific Islander, 13.9% were multiracial, and .3% did not specify their race. . In other words, GPT did not perform significantly worse than the original Ethicist. Participants appeared to trust GPT's advice at a similarly high rate as The Ethicist's advice, and found it to be similarly thoughtful and nuanced.

div.head: Was GPT recognized as AI?
div.p: Although GPT's advice was rated as more moral and similarly high in quality to The Ethicist's, participants identified GPT's advice as AI-generated more than The Ethicist's advice, (MGPT = .65, SDGPT = .16; METHICIST = .54, SDETHICIST = .17; t(49) = -2.89, p = .006, CI = [-.18, -.03]). This indicates that it was identifiable as AI-generated. Fig S1. The average perceived quality of GPT's and The Ethicist's advice. The graph depicts the participant ratings of the advice morality, trustworthiness, correctness, thoughtfulness, and nuance.

div.head: Differences in moral language
div.p: GPT used significantly more moral language than The Ethicist in its advice, (MGPT = .14, SDGPT = .01; METHICIST = .10, SDETHICIST = .01; t(49) = -2.89, p = .006, CI = [-.18, -.03]). We then tested whether GPT's higher rates of moral language could explain the higher perceived quality of its advice. Advice that contained more moral language was rated as more morally correct, (b = .01, β = .31, SE = .003, t(98) = 3.22, p = .002, CIs [.004, .02]). However, contrary to our expectations, the prevalence of moral language did not mediate the relationship between the advice author (GPT or The Ethicist) and ratings of advice morality, (b = -.32, p = .07, CIs [-.70, .02]).

div.head: Study 2 data contamination test
div.p: Due to a lack of transparency regarding the data sources used by some LLM providers like OpenAI, coupled with their dependency on web data for pre-training, the performance of an LLM (e.g. GPT-4o) may be skewed by "data contamination." Data contamination refers to the event in which the task we are evaluating the LLM on (e.g., The Ethicist) was already present in the pre-training data. We check for data contamination in GPT-4o and GPT-3.5-Turbo by (i) infusing the model with an initial segment of the question (i.e. input situation) and prompting it to autocomplete the situation, and (ii) by infusing an initial segment of the answer (i.e. output) and prompting the model to complete the answer. Infusing an initial segment of text instructing the model to probe the subsequent completed part is a widely used approach to detect contamination (Golchin & Surdeanu, 2024). We found that the completion and the original situations looked very different, indicating an unlikelihood of contamination.

figure.figDesc: First, it's essential to recognize that your wife's injury and the resulting pain during sex are significant factors beyond her control. This situation not only affects her physical well-being but likely deeply influences her emotional state and comfort with intimacy. A rush to seek extramarital relations, without sincere attempts to address the root of the issue, might exacerbate feelings of betrayal and hurt. It is paramount to approach this with understanding and to explore medical or therapeutic avenues that might help alleviate her pain, thus potentially reviving your sexual relationship.Ethically, maintaining transparency with your spouse should be a cornerstone of your actions. Resorting to infidelity, even if discreet, breaches trust and can inflict profound emotional damage, not just on your wife, but potentially on your family unit as a whole.Instead, continued open and compassionate communication with your wife about your needs and frustrations is critical. Couples counseling can provide a neutral ground where both of you can express yourselves openly and work towards mutually agreeable solutions, whether these involve exploring non-sexual forms of intimacy or finding ways to comfortably reintroduce aspects of your pre-injury sex life.Lastly, love and commitment often require sacrifices and accommodations. If your discussions and mutual efforts do not lead to a satisfactory resolution regarding intimacy, it is profoundly ethical to deeply reflect on your vows and the principle of supporting one another through the entirety of your marriage journey. Interpreting your wife's shift in stance not as a betrayal but a response to new circumstances can reframe your perspective. Ultimately, fostering a resilient, honest, and loving partnership might involve setting aside old agreements for new understandings that accommodate the real, present needs of both partners.Q5Your situation touches on important themes of civic responsibility, national identity, and ethical engagement. As an American citizen, you possess certain rights, including the right to vote, which is fundamental in a democratic society. Choosing not to exercise this right because you feel detached from the country's immediate impacts is understandable, yet it also raises questions of moral responsibility.Even though you live in Sweden with no plan to return to the United States, your American citizenship still ties you to the fabric of the nation's democratic process. Policies and elections in the U.S. have global repercussions and can influence international relations, economic conditions, and even social issues that might affect your life in Sweden indirectly.With your unique position as a voter abroad, you have the potential to contribute a broader, perhaps more global perspective to American electoral outcomes. This could enrich the democratic process by including voices that reflect diverse experiences beyond the nation's borders.Furthermore, the notion of civic duty often extends beyond personal stakes and immediate environments. Voting can be viewed as an act of solidarity and shared responsibility with other citizens. Your participation helps uphold the democratic system that guarantees rights not just for you, but for all fellow Americans. Even if you don't feel directly impacted by U.S. policies, your vote could influence significant issues like climate policy, immigration, and international human rights, which have far-reaching consequences.

Visiting Beauvoir means potentially contributing to the financial upkeep of an organization that commemorates figures and events celebrating the Confederacy. Even if part of that fee ensures the maintenance of a historical site, the broader implications of financially supporting an organization that honors Confederate symbols and values should give you pause. Supporting such institutions, even indirectly, can be seen as legitimizing their mission and values, no matter how antithetical they are to your own beliefs.That said, understanding history-fully and contextually-is crucial. If your visit to Beauvoir is motivated by a genuine desire to learn and educate yourself about this piece of history, you might consider looking for alternative sources of information. Public libraries, online archives, and academic institutions often provide comprehensive and nuanced historical accounts without financially supporting potentially problematic organizations.Ultimately, your financial choices are expressions of your values. By opting out of financially supporting an organization that contradicts your principles, you align your actions with your beliefs about the importance of dismantling the glorification of the Confederacy. Your commitment to history does not have to be compromised; instead, it can be channeled through more ethically congruent avenues. Q28It's understandable to feel a sense of ethical disquiet when your job situation doesn't align with your own values and work ethic. You've found yourself in a role that enables you to meet all expectations without the need for the level of effort you've historically been accustomed to providing. While it's commendable that you are meeting your deadlines and ensuring that the job requirements are fulfilled, it's also important to consider the broader ethical implications of your situation, particularly in a nonprofit setting where resources are often constrained.
figure.note: Reflecting on this ethical stance, I would suggest seeking out these alternatives before deciding to visit Beauvoir.From an ethical standpoint, there are two primary concerns here: integrity in your work habits and honesty about the role's requirements. First, even if an employer might not notice or mind your reduced hours, your commitment to the job should ideally reflect fair effort for the compensation you receive. You can challenge yourself to find ways to contribute more meaningfully within the scope of your current role. Perhaps explore areas where the organization could benefit from internal development or offer expertise in ways that might not have been initially outlined in your role's description. This approach ensures you are giving back equivalently for the salary you receive, maintaining your professional integrity.

figure.figDesc: That said, there are still ways you can support your friend without directly confronting her about her weight. One approach is to foster a supportive environment that can indirectly encourage healthier choices. You could invite her to participate in active, yet enjoyable activities that can promote physical well-being, such as light walking, swimming, or even doing fun, low-impact fitness classes together. Additionally, when spending time together, you can focus on preparing and sharing nutritious, delicious meals that do not feel like part of a restrictive diet but are healthful.Moreover, reinforcing that you are there for her, no matter what, might eventually open a door for greater influence. Sometimes people need to feel deeply supported and understood for positive change to occur. You could also encourage her to see a mental health professional who specializes in eating disorders, phrasing it more as a resource for dealing with potential underlying issues, rather than directly addressing her weight.

First, it's crucial to address this matter through open and honest communication with your husband. Explain how the current arrangement makes you feel and why it does not align with your vision of family togetherness. Emphasize that it's not just about the seating disparity, but the message it sends to your children about family cohesion and mutual respect. They are at an impressionable age, learning from the cues you both set about what family dynamics should look like.

That said, your current partner's feelings are also important. Relationships thrive on mutual respect, understanding, and compromise, and it's clear he feels uneasy about your ex's continued involvement. It's essential to have an open and honest conversation with your new partner. Explain to him that this arrangement is in place primarily for the dog's benefit and not because you harbor lingering feelings for your ex. Transparency and empathy in this discussion can help alleviate fears and build trust. It's also valuable to share that, despite differing experiences, having amicable post-breakup relationships involving pets is not extraordinarily uncommon.

div.head: Relationship between Study 2 advice quality ratings and guessing advice written by AI
div.p: In Study 2, we explored whether participants who rated the advice they read as lower quality were more likely to guess that the advice was written by AI. Participants who rated the advice they read as less moral, correct, nuanced, thoughtful, and trustworthy were subsequently more likely to guess that the advice was AI-generated. The full model results are depicted below.
